posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21585188
Though I smothered Cohen to death with a pillow, I am not his murderer. I was charged with a hate crime, but I did not do it out of hate. It was both, at once, a great mercy and a considerable contribution towards the continued protection of the general public. After I tell you of my sordid tale, of which I alone am left to tell, you will see why it is so unreasonable to keep me in this institution for long.

In the summer of 2019, I was a young man who had been disinherited of my Grandfather's immense fortune. Destitute, and near deprived of everything that should have rightfully been mine—save for snub-nosed revolver my Grandfather always carried on him; I had little choice for work.

It was to my then considerable fortune that I had chanced upon the old Kosher deli, and seeing that they had little in means of workers and were hiring, I figured that I would apply in spite of my reservations at the sight of the place. I did not know then, but my hesitation was a sign that I should have stayed well away from that cursed deli.

I walked into the deli with nothing but the clothes on my back and a near-empty wallet, and upon seeing the old proprietor of the deli, my hopes for any chance of employment collapsed entirely.

The old proprietor, known as Cohen, was as Jewish a man descended matrilineally of old Roman stock could get. His curled hair had long gone grey, yet his build was still stocky and powerful. He spoke with a overwhelmingly powerful Yiddish accent, and upon seeing me, greeted me in Yiddish, assuming me for one of his own.

I spoke to him, and told him that I was not there to purchase anything, but that I had seen his notice for employment and had come in to the shop, with little qualification save for my will to work for an honest wage, for the purpose of gaining employment within. His dark, indiscernable gaze fell upon me for but a moment, no doubt calculating the gains that could be squeezed out of a desperate young man, and the losses he could no doubt cheat me out of.

He then spoke to me, “When can you work?”

I told him, “Now or tomorrow.”

As it was very late in the day when I had come upon his shop, he bid me to come behind the counter, and as I did, the striking countenance of an ancient, decrepit wine box greeted me. I was briefly startled at the sight, for I recognized it for what it was, yet the owner, no doubt falling to his fouler instincts, said nothing of it and took me back.
(1/2)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21585195
He told me, in a Yiddish-English scop, that there was a small unused office at the back I could use as a room, and that I could hose myself down in the butchery room if I'd like, and that he'd have a uniform ready for me by tomorrow, and that I should turn in as soon as I could for he would call me at an ungodly, yet very Jewish time for work. I could understand the meaning of the old Jew, and I inwardly scoffed at his worse nature overtaking him. I said that I would return, and I walked out of the establishment to my car to get my possibles and spare clothing.

I should have driven away when I could have.

After I stowed my few belongings away into the unused office, where a spare, squeaky mattress had been taken out from somewhere and laid out for me, the old Jew showed me around the stations of butchery, and taught me the tricks of deep Jewry for cutting meat in a kosher way, and much else, before he told me to come with him and observe.

As he left the room, the once sterile and boring room seemed to come alive with a malicious intent. The hanging butcher hooks sank lower, the wet knives gleamed sharper, and the soaked concrete floor was all the more slippery. Each component of the Butchery, vital in their lonely use, had all come together in a secret covenant against my personage. Yet in spite of the maliciousness of the carving knives and cleavers haphazardly laid out on wet pink rags, there was nothing more desolate than the feeling of Jewishness that permeated the back. I shuddered and swiftly followed after the old Jew.

He stood there behind the counter, both hands laid flat on the clear glass pane, and slightly leaning forwards, waited for his next customer with a distinct eagerness that was altogether disturbingly familiar to me. It was the love of money that so ingrained itself to the Jewish race, that it was part of their soul, other than loud arguments over nothing and the propensity to being exiled from places of living. I stood there beside him, and beside the warped dusty wine box that remained tightly closed in spite of its disuse. God how that thing unsettled me most.

(2/2)

posts.sub: Was the backlash against Enid Blyton warrented?
posts.com:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Enid_Blyton
>A.H. Thompson, who compiled an extensive overview of censorship efforts in the United Kingdom's public libraries, dedicated an entire chapter to "The Enid Blyton Affair", and wrote of her in 1975:
>"No single author has caused more controversy among librarians, literary critics, teachers, and other educationalists and parents during the last thirty years, than Enid Blyton. How is it that the books of this tremendously popular writer for children should have given rise to accusations of censorship against librarians in Australia, New Zealand, and the United Kingdom?"[133]
>Blyton's range of plots and settings has been described as limited, repetitive and continually recycled.[72] Many of her books were critically assessed by teachers and librarians, deemed unfit for children to read, and removed from syllabuses and public libraries.[7] Responding to claims that her moral views were "dependably predictable",[134] Blyton commented that "most of you could write down perfectly correctly all the things that I believe in and stand for – you have found them in my books, and a writer's books are always a faithful reflection of himself".[135]
>From the 1930s to the 1950s the BBC operated a de facto ban on dramatising Blyton's books for radio, considering her to be a "second-rater" whose work was without literary merit.[136][137][f] The children's literary critic Margery Fisher likened Blyton's books to "slow poison",[7] and Jean E. Sutcliffe of the BBC's schools broadcast department wrote of Blyton's ability to churn out "mediocre material", noting that "her capacity to do so amounts to genius ... anyone else would have died of boredom long ago".[138] Michael Rosen, Children's Laureate from 2007 until 2009, wrote that "I find myself flinching at occasional bursts of snobbery and the assumed level of privilege of the children and families in the books."[123] The children's author Anne Fine presented an overview of the concerns about Blyton's work and responses to them on BBC Radio 4 in November 2008, in which she noted the "drip, drip, drip of disapproval" associated with the books.[139] Blyton's response to her critics was that she was uninterested in the views of anyone over the age of 12, stating that half the attacks on her work were motivated by jealousy and the rest came from "stupid people who don't know what they're talking about because they've never read any of my books".[140]

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Despite criticism by contemporaries that her work's quality began to suffer in the 1950s at the expense of its increasing volume, Blyton nevertheless capitalised on being generally regarded at the time as "a more 'savoury', English alternative" to what some considered an "invasion" of Britain by American culture, in the form of "rock music, horror comics, television, teenage culture, delinquency, and Disney".[15]
>According to British academic Nicholas Tucker, the works of Enid Blyton have been "banned from more public libraries over the years than is the case with any other adult or children's author", though such attempts to quell the popularity of her books over the years seem to have been largely unsuccessful, and "she still remains very widely read".[141]
>Simplicity
>Some librarians felt that Blyton's restricted use of language, a conscious product of her teaching background, was prejudicial to an appreciation of more literary qualities. In a scathing article published in Encounter in 1958, the journalist Colin Welch remarked that it was "hard to see how a diet of Miss Blyton could help with the 11-plus or even with the Cambridge English Tripos",[7] but reserved his harshest criticism for Blyton's Noddy, describing him as an "unnaturally priggish ... sanctimonious ... witless, spiritless, snivelling, sneaking doll."[57]
>The author and educational psychologist Nicholas Tucker notes that it was common to see Blyton cited as people's favourite or least favourite author according to their age, and argues that her books create an "encapsulated world for young readers that simply dissolves with age, leaving behind only memories of excitement and strong identification".[142] Fred Inglis considers Blyton's books to be technically easy to read, but to also be "emotionally and cognitively easy". He mentions that the psychologist Michael Woods believed that Blyton was different from many other older authors writing for children in that she seemed untroubled by presenting them with a world that differed from reality. Woods surmised that Blyton "was a child, she thought as a child, and wrote as a child ... the basic feeling is essentially pre-adolescent ... Enid Blyton has no moral dilemmas ... Inevitably Enid Blyton was labelled by rumour a child-hater. If true, such a fact should come as no surprise to us, for as a child herself all other children can be nothing but rivals for her."[143] Inglis argues though that Blyton was clearly devoted to children and put an enormous amount of energy into her work, with a powerful belief in "representing the crude moral diagrams and garish fantasies of a readership".[143] Blyton's daughter Imogen has stated that she "loved a relationship with children through her books", but real children were an intrusion, and there was no room for intruders in the world that Blyton occupied through her writing.[144]

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Accusations of racism, xenophobia and sexism
>Accusations of racism in Blyton's books were first made by Lena Jeger in a Guardian article published in 1966. In the context of discussing possible moves to restrict publications inciting racial hatred, Jeger was critical of Blyton's The Little Black Doll, originally published in 1937.[145][146] Sambo, the black doll of the title, is hated by his owner and other toys owing to his "ugly black face", and runs away. A shower of "magic rain" washes his face clean, after which he is welcomed back home with his now pink face.[147] Jamaica Kincaid also considers the Noddy books to be "deeply racist" because of the blonde children and the black golliwogs.[148] In Blyton's 1944 novel The Island of Adventure, a black servant named Jo-Jo is very intelligent, but is particularly cruel to the children.[149]
>Accusations of xenophobia were also made. As George Greenfield observed, "Enid was very much part of that between the wars middle class which believed that foreigners were untrustworthy or funny or sometimes both".[150] The publisher Macmillan conducted an internal assessment of Blyton's The Mystery That Never Was, submitted to them at the height of her fame in 1960. The review was carried out by the author and books editor Phyllis Hartnoll, in whose view "There is a faint but unattractive touch of old-fashioned xenophobia in the author's attitude to the thieves; they are 'foreign' ... and this seems to be regarded as sufficient to explain their criminality." Macmillan rejected the manuscript,[151] but it was published by William Collins in 1961,[152] and then again in 1965 and 1983.[151]
>Blyton's depictions of boys and girls are considered by many critics to be sexist.[153][154] In a Guardian article published in 2005 Lucy Mangan proposed that The Famous Five series depicts a power struggle between Julian, Dick and George (Georgina), in which the female characters either act like boys or are talked down to, as when Dick lectures George: "it's really time you gave up thinking you're as good as a boy".[155]

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Revisions to later editions
>To address criticisms levelled at Blyton's work, some later editions have been altered to reflect more politically progressive attitudes towards issues such as race, gender, violence between young persons, the treatment of children by adults, and legal changes in Britain as to what is allowable for young children to do in the years since the stories were originally written (e.g. purchasing fireworks); modern reprints of the Noddy series substitute teddy bears or goblins for golliwogs, for instance.[156] The golliwogs who steal Noddy's car and dump him naked in the Dark Wood in Here Comes Noddy Again are replaced by goblins in the 1986 revision, who strip Noddy only of his shoes and hat and return at the end of the story to apologise.[157]
>The Faraway Tree's Dame Slap, who made regular use of corporal punishment, was changed to Dame Snap who no longer did so, and the names of Dick and Fanny in the same series were changed to Rick and Frannie.[158] Characters in the Malory Towers and St. Clare's series are no longer spanked or threatened with a spanking, but are instead scolded. References to George's short hair making her look like a boy were removed in revisions to Five on a Hike Together, reflecting the idea that girls need not have long hair to be considered feminine or normal.[159] Anne of The Famous Five stating that boys cannot wear pretty dresses or like girls' dolls was removed.[160] In The Adventurous Four, the names of the young twin girls were changed from Jill and Mary to Pippa and Zoe.[161]
>In 2010 Hodder, the publisher of the Famous Five series, announced its intention to update the language used in the books, of which it sold more than half a million copies a year. The changes, which Hodder described as "subtle", mainly affect the dialogue rather than the narrative. For instance, "school tunic" becomes "uniform", "mother and father" and "mother and daddy" (this latter one used by young female characters and deemed sexist) become "mum and dad",[162] "bathing" is replaced by "swimming", and "jersey" by "jumper".[158] Some commentators see the changes as necessary to encourage modern readers,[162] whereas others regard them as unnecessary and patronising.[158] In 2016 Hodder's parent company Hachette announced that they would abandon the revisions as, based on feedback, they had not been a success.[163]

My wife is an MD neurologist. Her best friend and colleague was the head of Neurology at a major Chinese hospital. She raves to her about how smart I am.
I'm just a faggot online, but you'll just have to trust that I'm highly intelligent.

Now, to explain the book though, he is a dentist that traveled the world visiting tribal people and isolated people (gaelic swiss, eskimoes, Africans). You name it, he was there on scene.
He would compare the tribes or settlements that were isolated (mountain pass, poor roads, or just generally isolated by distance) to the ones that were near and/or influenced by a western diet of grains and sugar.
So you are then looking at highly similar genetic groups and attempting to find the main difference among the groups.
Western foods immediate destroyed their teeth and facial structure.
Perfect teeth and jaws no matter where you went until sugar and grain were introduced and then they had rotted teeth and malformed jaws that led also to crooked teeth.
It's documented with photography of the groups and their diets.

This was the same regardless of macro nutrient break down.
For instance the Gaelic swiss ate almost all dairy and cheese (the isolated by mountain passes ones).
The eskimoes ate almost zero carbohydrate.
The phillipinos ate almost 90% carbs.
All perfect teeth and jaws and generally attractive.
A single generation of western diet ruined it.
This was in the 20s or roundabouts.

I'm currently reading Life at the Bottom: The Worldview That Makes the Underclass. It's an essay collection written by a doctor/psychiatrist with lots of experience working in a British slum, a prison, and some of the poorest countries in Africa. It's about the troubles of the underclass, how their worldview shapes their actions, and how ideas pushed by intellectuals often aggravate their problems, even when their intentions are good. It's a pretty interesting read, so I definitely recommend it.

Murrah Federal Building and the period after his 1995 arrest until his 2001 execution. McVeigh's life, as Dr. Wendy Painting describes it, offers a backdrop for her discussion of not only several intimate and previously unknown details about him, but a number of episodes and circumstances in American History as well. In Aberration in the Heartland, Painting explores Cold War popular culture, all-American apocalyptic fervor, organized racism, contentious politics, militarism, warfare, conspiracy theories, bioethical controversies, mind control, the media's construction of villains and demons, and institutional secrecy and cover-ups. >>21559714
McVeigh, "lone wolf," types are reported placid, peaceful, disassociated upon apprehension, which is a state common to those successfully remade by "Debility, Dependency and Dread," aka DDD, the shorthand for a modern military menticide technique conceived by Dr. Jolyon West, an MKUltra psychologist.
Patty Hearst's few days of confinement and torture remade her into militant "Tania." Whatever one makes of Sirhan Sirhan, Ellroy refers to him as "drooling," but he's a far different candidate than a top-scoring special forces veteran with frontline combat experience, like McVeigh.
Aberration points out how the VA, by design, makes its combat-sculpted minds available to psychosurgical experimentation, medical opportunists, anyone with enough juice in town to test their gobbledygok in expendable soldiers. Many were shambling wrecks and if your quackery hurt them, who would even notice? That sort of exploitation generally goes back to the Manhattan Project, Slavery, etc.
What unites these stories is not only the idea of psychologic techniques but excellence in applying these dark arts: hypnosis, drugs, lobotomies, implants, NDE, "Plague Vaccines I, II or III," all can be sophisticated implementations of long-studied solutions to behavioral problems. Trauma and anxiety alone are said to increase someone's capacity to be hypnotized.
Perhaps the hypnotizability of a McVeigh, like an unstable air frame, requires scheduled maintenance. Why you would install hardware might have to do with acquiring highly motivated personnel: many times you cannot pay them or motivate them to work for you if they choose no to. There's no secret society holding McVeigh's wife or children. Plus, that has its limits too and maybe is ill-suited to clandestine security work.
Guns-to-temples is how we did Marines in Viet Nam and it worked well when you needed normal young people to do war crimes right now. But how do you systematize such power? What if you need years and years of uptime?
If you needed a longer operational span, more air time for McVeigh, maybe you needed to help him dig deeper than his conscience could, see beyond his judgement, it becomes difficult to fathom the DOD not packaging together a PATCON pacemaker for their deep cover infiltrator.
That photo shows an early version of such a system plugged into captured VC.

posts.sub: Hegel explains where physics went wrong
posts.com:
>At present, students of nature who are anxious to avoid metaphysics turn a favourable ear to Atomism. But it is not possible to escape metaphysics and cease to trace nature back to terms of thought, by throwing ourselves into the arms of Atomism. The atom, in fact, is itself a thought; and hence the theory which holds matter to consist of atoms is a metaphysical theory.

>Newton gave physics an express warning to beware of metaphysics, it is true, but to his honour be it said, he did not by any means obey his own warning. The only mere physicists are the animals: they alone do not think: while man is a thinking being and a born metaphysician. The real question is not whether we shall apply metaphysics, but whether our metaphysics are of the right kind: in other words, whether we are not, instead of the concrete logical Idea, adopting one-sided forms of thought, rigidly fixed by understanding, and making these the basis of our theoretical as well as our practical work. It is on this ground that one objects to the Atomic philosophy.

>The old Atomists viewed the world as a many, as their successors often do to this day. On chance they laid the task of collecting the atoms which float about in the void. But, after all, the nexus binding the many with one another is by no means a mere accident: as we have already remarked, the nexus founded on their very nature.

>To Kant we owe the completed theory of matter as the unity of repulsion and attraction. The theory is correct, so far as it recognises attraction to be the other of the two elements involved in the notion of being-for-self: and to be an element no less essential than repulsion to constitute matter. Still, this dynamic construction of matter, as it is termed, has the fault of taking for granted, instead of deducing, attraction and repulsion. Had they been deduced, we should then have seen the How and Why of a unity which is merely asserted. Kant ... [insisted that] matter must be regarded as consisting solely in their unity.

>German physicists for some time accepted this pure dynamic. But in spite of this, the majority of these physicists in modern times have found it more convenient to return to the Atomic point of view, and in spite of the warnings of Kästner, one of their number, have begun to regard Matter as consisting of infinitesimally small particles, termed ‘atoms which atoms have then to be brought into relation with one another by the play of forces attaching to them-attractive, repulsive, or whatever they may be. This too is metaphysics; and metaphysics which, for its utter unintelligence, there would be sufficient reason to guard against.

Is as true now as it was then...

>>21581675
It is based on a real happening of a regional scandal of a (semi)-doctors wife, the news reporting on it made Parisian/national press and Flaubert read about it. Flaubert also grew up in a hospital which his father was head surgeon and administrator of, Mister Bovary was of a new legal class of semi-doctors who were only half-trained and could only perform limited procedures (definitely not foot surgery). The medical establishment looked down on them as buffoons, part of Flaubert's venom is that received medico view against this new doltish class of semi-doctors. The semi-doctor class was eventually abolished in the late 19th century by the French state, and otherwise forgotten about.

>>21581675
I would surmise two lines of critique. The first is that the bourgeoisie mode of life stifles the realisation of human potential or wants, Charles is a boring soulless dolt, Emma has a churning interior life unable to find expression or satisfaction as a small town doctors wife.

The second is a critique of romanticism, which despite its pretences of enabling the expression of inner-life, is unable to realise human potential in an actual socialised way, none of the romantic solutions offer a mode of life, only episodic pangs and paroxysm. Romanticism inflammes inner feelings that it offers no means of realising as a mode of life, the affairs and financial escapism are more theatrical spasms than a real way of living, and end in very unromantic and very cruel ruin.

Flaubert's pessmissm is of a diagnostic-skeptical, rather ontological type. He analyses a picturesque bourgoise/provincial life and finds it wanting, he plays out romanticism as a solution in its full life-arc, rather than the epsiodes and spasms of the romantics themselves, and finds it wanting too.

>>21584917
>He argues also that there's little chance that another Industrial Revolution would occur after a collapse since most of the easily-accessible resources that allowed it to emerge have long been depleted (eg coal, oil, gas that now require advanced machinery to extract).

This is very accurate, since this is precisely what happened after the fall of the Roman Empire.
For example, the depletion of Pozzolana led the infrastructure of the later empire to be not as enduring, since buildings would then be made of terracotta (much less durable) or, in the best case scenarios, lime mortar (that was scarce and mostly reserved to churches/fortifications). Through most of the middle ages, Europe returned to be dependent on wood in order to build most civil infrastructure.

The fall of our current tech society would be an even greater collapse, since no modern human in the West has the artisanship to build simple but necessary tools. After all, how many people that you know can bend the iron to build a hoe or an axe? Or how many people in New York have the knowledge of making ropes? Or perhaps civil woodworking without buying planks in the general store?
We know nothing about how the things we use daily are made. Assembly lines atomized labour to a point that a person who knows how to use a screwdriver know nothing about making screws.

posts.name: Anti-Tech Retard

>>21585155
Yes. But Nuclear has a number of problems, on which are mostly related to politics. The bureaucracy is enormous, making it an undesirable investment for most private corporations, it yields more energy upon energetic investment, but it's by far the most expensive energy business to maintain. The second problem is party politics, which are public concerns over this technology (look what the greens are doing in Germany).

Now, hydro is a whole different case (clean in emissions, but terrible for wildlife), and it depends on environmental factors (well, it gotta rain in a regular basis). Paraguay, a small country in South America, has 100% of it's electricity generated by hydro, which they actually purchase from Brazil and Argentina, countries with immense rivers if compared to rivers in North America/Europe. However, recently Paraguay started to face problems, since a drought in the region forced these dams to operate at a low capacity, increasing much of the energy prices for landlocked Paraguay. Since climate change means less rain during the dry season and the dams aren't able to retain much water (when the water exceeds, they open the floodgates), this alternative is questionable.
To maintain its overcrowded cities, Brazil resourced to the great villain of green politics: coal plants.

So you see the problem...
The future is grim, bruh.

And forget about fusion. Even the most optimistic defenders of it admitted that it will take decades, perhaps a century, for it to be commercialized.

This video explains the problem well. It's based on old data, but it didn't change much.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
How Nietzsche means by ‘good and evil’ shifts a little from book to book in the later period (post-Zarathustra) texts. I don’t think Nietzsche’s main point is that ‘good and evil’ do or do not exist in some metaphysical or ontological sense. Instead, I think it might be helpful to contrast ‘good and evil’ with ‘good and bad’. I can’t recall if it’s in BGE or in the Genealogy, but in one or the other N. Says that ‘beyond good and evil’ certainly doesn’t mean ‘beyond good and bad’. So how does Nietzsche contrast the two? Since I take ‘good and bad’ to be an evaluative couplet Nietzsche (sort of) endorses, while ‘good and evil’ is not an evaluative couplet Nietzsche endorses. How I take Nietzsche to mean is: ‘good and bad’ is a ‘natural’ or ‘basic’ way to evaluate, whereas ‘good and evil’ is an incorrect way to evaluate. So ‘good and bad’ might include basic do’s and don’ts e.g. do eat, drink, copulate, exercise; don’t drown yourself, don’t starve yourself, don’t catch leprosy. Whereas ‘good and evil’ is like an expansion pack that modifies the original sorting; instead of ‘sex is good because it’s a part of our species nature’ to ‘sex is EVIL since it dirties the soul and continues our wretched species’.
There is a LOT more to say. Happy to talk. But my main takeway point is: ‘good and evil’ are terms in an evaluative framework that Nietzsche takes as misinterpreting how people/life works. You should avoid thinking in terms of ‘good and evil’ while inquiring/rooting out the ways you implicitly do think and act in accord with those terms.

Once upon a time, in the wild west, there was a cowboy named Jack. He was a solitary figure, known for his quick draw and deadly aim with a revolver. He had no family or friends, just a burning desire to right wrongs and protect the innocent.

Jack rode into the dusty town of Deadwood one day, looking for work as a gunslinger. The local outlaws had been terrorizing the townspeople, and the mayor had put out a call for someone to bring them to justice. Jack knew this was his chance to make a name for himself and rid the town of its troubles.

He went to the saloon and ordered a whiskey, sizing up the patrons as he did so. A group of rough-looking men sat in the corner, laughing and boasting about the robberies they had committed. Jack knew they were the ones he was looking for.

He finished his drink and approached the group, his hand hovering over his gun. "You boys have been causing trouble in this town," he said, his voice low and menacing. "I'm here to put a stop to it."

The outlaws sneered at him, thinking him to be just another cowboy looking for a quick buck. But they were wrong. Jack was a seasoned gunslinger, and he was not to be underestimated.

With lightning speed, he drew his revolver and fired, taking down the leader of the group with one shot. The other outlaws scrambled for their guns, but they were no match for Jack's skill and precision. In the blink of an eye, the outlaws were all lying dead on the saloon floor.

The townspeople were shocked and amazed by the stranger who had saved them from the terror of the outlaws. They hailed him as a hero and offered him a job as the town's marshal. Jack accepted, knowing that he had found a purpose in life.

He spent the rest of his days protecting the town and its people, always ready to draw his revolver at a moment's notice. And when he finally passed on, he was remembered as a legend of the wild west, a cowboy who had tamed the lawless land with his gun.

Once upon a time, there was a young boy named Tim who was a nudist. He believed that being naked was the most natural and liberating thing in the world. He would often go for walks in the woods near his home, enjoying the feeling of the sun and the breeze on his skin.

One day, while he was out on one of his walks, he was caught by a group of bullies from his school. They had been following him and had been waiting for the perfect opportunity to humiliate him. They started to tease and mock him, calling him names and making fun of his nudity.

Tim tried to explain to them that he was a nudist and that there was nothing wrong with being naked, but the bullies didn't want to hear it. They continued to mock and humiliate him, pushing him around and making him feel ashamed of who he was.

Feeling embarrassed and defeated, Tim ran home, where he locked himself in his room and cried. He couldn't believe that he had been bullied for something that was so important to him.

But Tim didn't let the experience defeat him. He knew that he had nothing to be ashamed of and that he should be proud of who he was. He decided to stand up for himself and tell his bullies that they couldn't make him feel ashamed of his beliefs.

The next day, Tim went to school and confronted his bullies. He told them that he was a nudist and that there was nothing wrong with being naked. He explained that everyone should be able to be themselves without fear of being bullied.

To Tim's surprise, his bullies apologized and admitted that they didn't understand what being a nudist meant. They realized that they had been wrong and that Tim had nothing to be ashamed of.

From that day on, Tim was no longer bullied and was able to be himself without fear of being ridiculed. He had stood up for himself and had shown others that it was okay to be different.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Once upon a time, Genghis Khan was a powerful and feared leader of the Mongol Empire. He had just defeated one of his enemies in battle and had taken the enemy's wife, mother, and daughter as prisoners.

As he was preparing to set up camp for the night, he noticed that the three women were completely naked. They had been stripped of their clothes as a sign of their defeat and submission to Genghis Khan.

Genghis Khan was a fierce warrior, but he was also a man of honor. He decided that the women should not be treated as mere spoils of war and that they should be treated with respect.

He ordered his men to give the women clothes and to provide them with food and shelter for the night. He also ordered his men to stay away from the women and to leave them alone.

That night, Genghis Khan sat with the women by the campfire and talked to them. He learned about their lives and their families, and they learned about his. He realized that they were not just his enemies, but also mothers, wives, and daughters, just like the women in his own life.

As the night went on, Genghis Khan began to see the humanity in the women and he began to understand that war was not only about winning and losing, but also about the people caught in the middle. He felt remorse for the violence and destruction he had caused, but he also knew that it was his duty as a leader to protect his people.

The next day, Genghis Khan released the women, giving them safe passage back to their own people. He also gave them gifts and provisions for their journey home. He knew that the women would always remember that one night when an enemy treated them with kindness and compassion.

From that day on, Genghis Khan's reputation as a leader changed. He was not only known as a fierce warrior, but also as a leader who understood the value of humanity and compassion, even in war.

>Rota, in describing von Neumann's relationship with his friend Stanislaw Ulam, wrote that von Neumann had "deep-seated and recurring self-doubts". All literature is usually considered inferior, does not matter what it is there is going to be a sizable group which hates it. Successful literature all has depth, does not matter if it is literary, crime, children's, or horror, it just uses that depth in a different way; the difference is how each uses that depth. In horror the depth is an exploitation of what is innate in most people and the author has to have a good understanding of that to scare people, they can't just say boo and expect it to work. Ultimately the depth comes down to the reader, do you use horror for a cheap thrill or to understand something about the fears we all have? this is why people often view horror as inferior, most of its readership use it for cheap thrills, they ignore the depth and this is part of the fundamental flaw in horror and most genre, analysis ruins the magic.

oh damn I've had the same question on my mind.
Ok, so Machiavelli says that there's 4 main ways to achieve power

1. by arms
2. by others
3. by merit
4. by fortune

I would then assume the value of literature is the acquisition of power by merit in parallel to your various species of developing power by arms.
The forms of literature that would most broadly represent literature would then be archetypal expressions of how one would express power through merit, and how someone who has power by merit would navigate a society founded upon arms, others, fortune, or a lack of merit.

I have composed an encyclopedia with this line of logic to defend it and the works are as follows:
Express power through merit: Dune, The six books Frank Herbert wrote
Navigate society of power through arms: The Lord of the Rings by J. R. R. Tolkien
of power through others: Atlas Shrugged by Ayn Rand
Fortune: Infinite Jest by David Foster Wallace
Lack of merit: The Stand by Stephen King

In dune the main crisis is that everyone needs to be exceptionally capable now that the highly advanced society can't rely on technology
In the Lord of the Rings everyone is concerned with having the most powerful weapon, a ring that basically gives anyone the power of a dictator (except Tom Bombadil)
In Atlas Shrugged everyone expects that other people will help them out (except Dagny Taggart)
In Infinite Jest everyone is trying to improve their chances of success or fortune (except Mario Incandenza)
In The Stand nearly everyone gets wiped out and it's total anarchy where no one can be expected to be competent

I'm halfway through Infinite Jest, a third of the way through Atlas Shrugged, like 150 pages into Rings Lord and only read the first couple chapters of Dune and The Stand.
I also only defined this encyclopedia and started reading like in this past month so Dune and The Stand might be more tentative but I'm pretty sure all of my a priori logic is sound.

>and how to get into it
What I've noticed is that every branch of criticism for X art form starts out excellent since they see criticism as an end in itself, and have some point they noticed about the original work that they really want to communicate. Over time, criticism declines because the above people are replaced, either by people who simply want to turn a profit (because criticism is really entertaining to the masses) or by ideologues who want to use the work as ammo with no respect to the art itself.

They say lit criticism peaked in the 19th century, but I'm still really curious about the first generation in the 17th century or so for this reason

posts.com:
As far as I know it's a about christianity and polytheism. It barely makes sense if you read it in a straightforward way. Ishmael means something like 'he who hears god'. Thus he seems to represent the search by the author to look for a fit religion. Ahab is a figure from the old testament who didn't worship Jehova but another god I think. Whales are described as Leviathans, whale hunting thus representing something as going head to head with the most terrible and dangerous challenges and difficulties of the world. Christianity doesn't seem to be the best for that according to the book. The harpoonmen who became too pious became worse at their job.

I'm still reading it but as far I know the author seems to fancy the old polytheistic religions more than christianity. Which you probably had to write in an allegorical way in the time it was written.

In "Sources of Slavic Pre-Christian Religion" Juan Antonio Álvarez-Pedrosa presents the original texts as well as English translations of all known medieval sources that inform us about the religion practiced by the Slavs before their Christianization. Since the Slavs did not have a written culture before their conversion to Christianity, all the texts were authored by people who were involved in this long process or in contact with the Slavs. For this reason, the texts come from a lengthy period from the ninth to the fifteenth century. Since the texts were originally written in seven different ancient languages, the present book is the result of the work of a large team of specialists.

>>21578816
>How would you recognize it?
I would recognize it simply by reading the material. I have seen many moments in literature where people approached what Shakespeare did, and there are even some films that here and there touch something of his poetic brilliance. Some moments of “Sweet Smell of Success” or “Network” come to mind. Other moments in literature where I have seen verbal imaginations that we’re doing things that were as great as what Shakespeare did are The Book of Job, the poems of Emily Dickinson and many passages of Fernando Pessoa.
>What makes Shakespeare's poetry great in your opinion
Above all other things what makes his poetry great, to my taste, is his gift for imagery, his unconcerned with sounding bombastic or ridiculous in his constant pursuit of saying all things in new and inventive ways. His fertility with metaphor and simile is the greatest I have ever seen, and he is constantly speaking about abstract things using concrete imagery. Life, death, time, ambition, honor, fear: he uses images to give flesh to this abstract concepts.
And the wonderful thing is that he used this gift for language to speak about all things. He didn’t had a fixed kernel of obsessions that dominated his work; what he did was to take stories from all kind of sources and deal with all sorts of themes, as if he didn’t had any rigid opinion about anything, and because of that he used his wonderful imagery to describe all sorts of minds, creeds, philosophical tastes, rules of life, world visions, etc.

I would recognize a new Shakespeare in a person who didn’t give a damn about realistic language and wrote poetic language as inventive as Job, Melville and Dickinson, but who could also work with several different subjects, themes, characters, atmospheres, plots, etc, jumping from one genre to other and then to other as if it were no big deal.

The major writer after Shakespeare I view as most similar (besides poets and playwrights of around the same time and up to the Romantic movement in poetry, the best of whom can be compared to Shakespeare and often were even explicitly inspired by him, as these comparisons are too easy), is Herman Melville, in Moby Dick especially, and he garnered high praise for it.

Another writer worthy of comparison to Shakespeare is Faulkner, with his polyvocality or polyphony, frequent Biblical allusions, dense and highly metaphorical language, as well as stream-of-consciousness monologues recreating the passion, beauty and depth of the best of Shakespeare’s soliloquies and monologues, and he also gets high praise.

Joyce’s Ulysses is another obvious contender for comparison but with quite a bit more modernist trickery and density.

This anon also mentions Pynchon’s Mason & Dixon, >>21579672, I also see some of the similarities but think it’s easy to see more similarity than there ultimately is simply because of Pynchon employing the archaic style of English that seems similar on its face to Shakespearean English; but it’s one of his greatest works, if not his greatest work, and in its best passages can be compared to Shakespeare, along with the genre-spanning, blend of comedy and tragedy. And historically M&D wasn’t published to high critical praise that long ago— John Barth also has an analogous achievement in his “The Sot-Weed Factor,” historical fiction on early America written in the same ye olde English as Pynchon employs.

Accredited fact checkers hereby declare OP’s post DEBUNKED, if you’re good enough you can get away with writing like Shakespeare, as long as you also have some originality and aren’t just trying to make a rehash of him.

If you willfully refuse to see similarities, you can always and only point out the differences. Of course, reading Melville or Faulkner is a much different experience from each other and both from Shakespeare, and few have the metaphorical density of Shakespeare (“ten similes in one line” as you put it). Even if Melville doesn’t have such density, passages like these are still some of the closest you’ll get to Shakespearean monologues in prose or literary (non-play) dialogue, in my opinion:

Consider the subtleness of the sea; how its most dreaded creatures glide under water, unapparent for the most part, and treacherously hidden beneath the loveliest tints of azure. Consider also the devilish brilliance and beauty of many of its most remorseless tribes, as the dainty embellished shape of many species of sharks. Consider, once more, the universal cannibalism of the sea; all whose creatures prey upon each other, carrying on eternal war since the world began.

Consider all this; and then turn to the green, gentle, and most docile earth; consider them both, the sea and the land; and do you not find a strange analogy to something in yourself? For as this appalling ocean surrounds the verdant land, so in the soul of man there lies one insular Tahiti, full of peace and joy, but encompassed by all the horrors of the half-known life. God keep thee! Push not off from that isle, thou canst never return!

Another anon here, its funny you talk of Melville, reading and wondering at Moby Dick is what turned me on to The Bard of Avon. Currently halfway through my personal Shakespeare Challenge, I'm reading everything written by him so I can truly say I understand Shakespeare.

After getting much more fluent with the Elizabethan vocabulary and prose, reading some of his earlier plays (The Comedy of Errors, Two Gentleman of Verona, currently reading Henry VI), then going *back* to his much better later works that one didn't originally appreciate, is an incredible experience. Where before Iago's monologues in Othello where these needlessly baroque word puzzles, they now start to flow, you better appreciate the beautiful metaphors chained together with such lovely prose. Reading some of the more eloquent or famous passages, I feel like they're...blasting from off of the page. I know it sounds stupid, far better minds than mine have described it, but one starts to feel like they are..."witnessing" genius, something strange and unprecedented.

Anyway, I just wanted to say, Shakespeare is legit.
